statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
The Seattle SuperSonics' longest losing streak in
more than a dozen years is finally over.
article.headline: Sonics' longest skid since '90 now history
article.linkText: Sonics trip Grizzlies in OT to snap six-game skid
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- The Seattle SuperSonics' longest losing streak in more than a dozen years is finally over.
Payton

Gary Payton scored seven of his 27 points in overtime and the Sonics snapped a six-game skid, beating the Memphis Grizzlies 103-97 Friday night. It was Seattle's worst slump since 1990, and it included losses at the Key Arena against Denver, the Los Angeles Clippers and Cleveland. The Sonics had lost 10 out of their previous 12. Rashard Lewis scored 24 points for Seattle, which hadn't won since Dec. 30 and hadn't broken 100 points since Dec. 16. "It feels good,'' Lewis said. "When you're losing games to teams like Denver and the Clippers, that's kind of embarrassing. So we wanted to come out and get this win.'' Desmond Mason's layup, Lewis' 12-foot baseline leaner and Payton's 17-footer gave Seattle a 94-88 lead in the first 1½ minutes of overtime. Payton's 3-pointer with 28.1 seconds left gave Seattle a 101-94 advantage. "The most important thing was to walk out of here with a win,'' Mason said with a grin. "I think we came out more aggressive on the offensive end and the defensive end, too.'' Payton almost had a triple double, finishing with 11 rebounds and nine assists. Mason added 20 points for the Sonics. For Memphis, Pau Gasol and Lorenzen Wright each scored 21 points, with Gasol grabbing 14 rebounds. The loss ended Memphis' six-game trip and dropped the Grizzlies to 2-18 on the road. Coach Hubie Brown said the Grizzlies were done in by their 1-for-12 shooting from 3-point range. "We had a ton of wide-open 3s, which is our game,'' Brown said. "But I give a lot of credit to Gary Payton. He made the big plays. And Lewis and Mason did an excellent job for them. Those guys were supporting Gary time and time again.'' Memphis rookie forward Drew Gooden said it was getting demoralizing to lose on the road, especially a game the Grizzlies could have won. "We've been in that position before, but it all comes down to making plays and not making mistakes,'' Gooden said. Brevin Knight's 18-footer tied it at 88 with 1.5 seconds left in regulation. Payton missed a 3-point attempt as time expired. While the Sonics made six of nine shots in overtime, the Grizzlies were two for six. Wright's offensive rebound and putback of Knight's missed layup with 31.4 seconds tied the score at 86. Lewis made two free throws with 55.8 seconds remaining to give the Sonics an 86-84 lead. The Sonics were in front 60-43 in the third quarter before the Grizzlies scored 11 straight to cut the deficit to 60-54 on Wright's three-point play with 3:20 left in the period. Memphis cut its deficit to 64-59 before Mason's jump shot gave Seattle a 68-61 lead at the end of the quarter. At halftime, the Sonics led 53-35, with their biggest lead at 51-31 after a steal and a driving layup by Kenny Anderson with 1:53 left in the second quarter. Seattle coach Nate McMillan said he couldn't believe his team blew its big lead. "It's disappointing to see that happen,'' he said. "We just weren't able to get anything going in the second half.'' The Sonics went on an 8-0 run in the opening quarter, including a pair of lay-ups by Lewis, for a 19-9 lead with 4:11 left in the period. Game notes
McMillan finally got his 100th coaching victory. ... Vladimir Radmanovic of the Sonics missed his second straight game because of a sprained right ankle. ... The Sonics blew a 15-point halftime lead at Utah Thursday night. ... The Sonics lost in Memphis 117-99 in the teams' first game of the season. The teams play again in Memphis on Jan. 25 and in Seattle on March 28. ... Payton went to the doctor before the game to have his throat examined. He was knocked to the floor Thursday night by an elbow by Utah's John Stockton. "I don't think it was done on purpose,'' McMillan said before the game. "Stockton was just trying to protect the ball.''
